name: 勞維俊
objective: 科學與技術是了解這個世界和我們自己一項強而有力的工具，而許多作家們對於這樣的情況也在他們的作品中給予各式各樣的回應。在這個課程中我們將學習到作家們如何在他們的作品中使用文學藝術技巧來詮釋與解讀科技與現代文學的相互作用；人類與大自然的關係；以及人類當前的處境。修習這門課程的學生並不需要具備對科學有嚴格的基礎訓練與知識，只要具備強烈的好奇心和求知慾。在課程的一開始我們將藉由閱讀相關作品讓大家熟悉一些重要的議題。課程的中心主題除了針對科學技術與文學的相互關係外，我們也將焦點放在分析文學作品上。我們將繼續探索文學形式與內容的關聯。同時，我們也將利用現代科技在課堂上練習文學作品的即興創作。學生們一開始分析一段正文的內容。然後他們利用這些片段重新組合成一篇新的文本。接著，在這些文本內建立新的超連結︰每當文本被閱讀時，讀者能有多種選擇來閱讀並且使正文成為一個完全新的實體。

Course Description:

By close readings of cultural texts including literature, film, architecture and the city, this course examines the relationship between technology, culture and modernity, exploring the extent to which technology could be regarded as neutral and progressive. Informed by critical theory, this course examines how technology shapes our ways of seeing, conception of ourselves, and relationship with others. 

Teaching Plan (subject to change):

1. Introduction: On Technology, the Mechanical and Modernity
Modern Times (dir. Charlie Chaplin) (Cf. Raymond Williams, Key Words)

2. The Mechanical Age
Dickens, Hard Times (chs. 1-2)
Thomas Carlyle, ‘Signs of the Times’ (1829)

3. No Class (International Conference)

4. The Mechanical Age (continued)

5. ‘Dirty’ and ‘Clean’ Technology
D. H. Lawrence, ‘Odour of Chrysanthemums’
E.T.A. Hoffmann, ‘The Mines of Falun’

6. Technology and Modernity 
Heidegger, ‘Question Concerning Technology’

7. No Class (University Holiday)

8. The Machine and the Body I
Freud, ‘The Uncanny’
E.T.A. Hoffmann (1776-1822), ‘The Sandman’
Thomas Hobbes on ‘the Artificial Man’
Descartes on mind and body

9. Mid-term

10. The Machine and the Body II
Kafka, ‘In the Penal Colony’
I’m a Cyborg, But That’s OK (dir. Park Chan-wook)
Cf. Donna Haraway, ‘A Cyborg Manifesto’

11. Dystopia and the Critiques to Technology
Aldous Huxley, Brave New World (chapter 1)

12. Art and Politics
Benjamin, ‘The Work of Art in Age of Its Technological Reproducibility’

13. The Machine and the Body III:

Cf. Lacan, ‘The Mirror Stage’

14. The Machine and the Body IV:

Easy Rider (1969, dir. Dennis Hopper) 
Cf. - Barthes, Camera Lucida
- Foucault, Discipline and Punish

15-16. Technology and the Global War

Empire of the Sun (1987, dir. Steven Spielberg) 
Georg Trakl, ‘Grodek’
Henry Reed, ‘Naming of Parts’ 
Cf. - Umberto Eco, Travels in Hyper Reality 
- Spivak, ‘Terror: A Speech After 9-11’
- T. J. Clark et al (eds.), Afflicted Powers 

17. Group Presentation 

18. Final Paper Due

Assessment: 

Participation　　　　　　　　　　 　　　　　　　　　　　　10%
Mid-term paper　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　30%
Group presentation 　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　20%
Final paper 　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　40%
　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　   100%　　

Mid-term paper:
Write an essay on a topic discussed during weeks 1-8. Possible essay titles will be announced during the lectures. The essay should focus on one cultural text and at least one cultural critic studied. A draft should be turned in for comment by week 7.

Final paper:
Write an essay on a topic discussed after the mid-term, during weeks 10-16. The essay should focus on one cultural text. You may compare it with a text discussed during weeks 1-8, but do not repeat yourself. A draft should be turned for comment by week 16.

Group Presentation:
The group should consist of 2-3 students. 
Option 1: to present on a chosen topic which allows critical analysis of an everyday issue concerning technology. Possible topics will be announced during the lectures. 
Option 2: to make a short film (around 15 min.) on a topic agreed by the instructor.

Site visit:
A site visit may be arranged. Possible activities: Museum visit, city field study, including shopping mall, park, library, transportation network, etc. Details to be confirmed.

A Note on Plagiarism: 
Please make sure your works are original and contain no unacknowledged materials. Plagiarism is an offense in the academic field, and Taipei Tech. takes it very seriously. The minimum penalty for plagiarism is a straight Fail in the course and the case may be passed on to the university for record.
